So, the inside of the ISS is held at 14.7 psi, with a vacuum on the other side.  O ring technology is not new.  As a scuba diver, we use O rings to seal the on/off shaft of a scuba tank which needs to withstand, in some cases, up to 4500 psi. So while this may be an awe moment, I am quite sure that there are  multiple sealing o rings along the shaft.  As the astronaut stated, there are emergency procedures to take, and NASA being who they are, have a full retro-fit repair program in place.

The vacuum of space is far less than people realise. The pressure differential is equivalent of snorkeling down to 10 meters. It's +1 bar  pressure at 10m compared to the surface, whereas space is -1 bar compared to surface pressure at sea level. So as you can see,  submarines are engineered to withstand so much more pressure differential. This is why the space station can be very thin walled. Only difference is that Pressure is trying to escape Vs pressure trying to get in in a submarine.

People are taught to think from movies and such that the difference between atmospheric pressure and a vacuum is a ton and makes things explode if there’s a leak, but in reality, it’s only 14.7 PSI. thing is, I know its got to have safety margins and redundancies and the consequences of failure are potentially extreme which means the engineering has to be excellent in design and construction but still, at the end of the day the pressure differential is only 1atm. everything from submarines to innumerable industrial processes operate with far, far higher differentials. people often feel that the vacuum of space must provide the ultimate pressure differential, but not so. the pressure difference between the inside and outside of an average car tyre is roughly 1.5x bigger than the difference between the inside and outside of the ISS. an industrial pressure gauge might be reading via a mechanical linkage across a pressure differential hundreds of times greater.

[Didn't you notice how the entire world was lulled into the erroneous belief that commercial airliners could bring down 2 skyscrapers, making them dissolve into clouds of dust and then disappear, with whatever was left falling perfectly into their own footprints like some miraculous occurrence just by chance (the buildings didn't fall over asymmetrically but rather they fell straight downward in such a way that you could not ask for a more perfect demolition). Then we have that tragic day in Dallas when our beloved Commander in Chief was cut down right before our eyes in what was a horrific event that was so clearly not possibly done by one person from the Texas School Book Depository. Just as the doctor at the press conference that day held his forefinger up to his own right temple to describe the shot coming in from the right side... and yet for some reason most of the American public believes that Lee Oswald did it.
Oswald is said to have done this, and he gets away... then he goes several miles away where he goes home and changes his clothes. What about "Scientifically Possible"? Is it even remotely "Scientifically Possible" for man to venture out into space? Lets assume that we could get past the low earth orbit barrier of the Van Allen Radiation Belt. Lets take that out of the equation for the sake of this argument... In the first place we cannot even achieve such an environment here on earth in which we could use to test the equipment that would be needed.

Late to this video ... just saw it today. SO I might be replying with repeated information. Here, on Earth, we have systems that are running pressures far beyond the differences between inside and outside the Station. Everyone thinks there's something different about the "vacuum of space" to "vacuum" on the surface. The term "vacuum" just describes less pressure than we live in. Even in space, the outside "vacuum" is just 0 PSI. It's not "less" than that. So, even if the pressure inside the Station was 14.7 PSI, the difference is still only ... 14.7 PSI to 0 PSI.
Aircraft use hydraulic pistons to operate the control surfaces. The pressure difference across the seals on those piston is around 3000 PSI. O-rings are more than capable of keeping air pressure in the Station.

Why do people have so much trouble understanding vacuum? I worked at a cyclotron which used lots of O-ring seals, mostly static, some sliding and some rotating like those described in the video. The only ones that ever failed were the sliding ones, which occasionally needed to be removed and re-greased. "Failure" meant that the pressure in the vacuum system rose from its normal level of 10-7mBar to, in a bad case, 10-4mBar. Now that is a bad thing for a cyclotron, but a leak of that magnitude on the ISS would do what? Absolutely nothing. I doubt if they could even detect it, let alone find out where it was. They lose orders of magnitude more gas every time they use the airlock, because they only de-pressurize the airlock to 5psi before venting it to space.

As amazing as it is, the principles are actually quite old compared to the mechanism itself. When you think about it, we've been using O-rings for decades to seal certain things from other certain things.

I work in the hydraulics field and you'd be surprised how high a pressure a pissy little O-ring can withstand when placed into a properly dimensioned and machined groove and sealing surface.

Would you go to the Moon in this joke?

The Lunar Module Challenger—the 17.9 x 14 x 13.3-foot spider spacecraft that took Apollo 17 astronauts Eugene Cernan and Harrison Schmitt to the surface of the Moon while Command Module Pilot Roland Evans orbited above them. If it looks fragile to you is because it was fragile. Or better said, strong enough to carry its mission but too fragile to fly anywhere but in space or the Moon.

At the time, the priority was to make it as light as humanly possible and give enough space to the astronauts inside, as well as any tools they needed (and to bring rocks from its surface on its way back to the Command Module). The ascent stage—which you can see in the photo—was only 10,300 pounds including its frame, engines, fuel, crew seats and the on-board computer. To give you an idea on how fragile this amazing spacecraft was, its walls were only 0.012 inches thick (0.03 centimeters) at some points. That's as thick as a paper sheet.

Interesting. That type of seal is very common in soft(low) vacuum equipment. There are better seals using a metal bellows with an internal crank that work at much harder vacuum - but obviously a 'leak' at the sort of levels you'll get through this type of seal is considered insignificant.

Shortfalls in cosmic ray (CR) propagation models obscure the CR sources and acceleration mechanisms. This problem became particularly obvious after the Fermi, Pamela, and AMS-02 have discovered the electron/positron and p/He spectral anomalies. Most of the CR models use diffusive propagation that is inaccurate for weakly scattered energetic particles. So, some parts of the spectra affected by the heliospheric modulation, for example, cannot be interpreted. I discuss and adopt an exact solution of the Fokker-Planck equation arXiv1610.01584, which gives a complete description of a ballistic, diffusive and transdiffusive (intermediate between the first two) propagation regimes. Then you have garage equipment with pressure regulators, solenoids, valves etc working to seal against 200 psi to 1500 psi..

The difference between good engineering and bad engineering is the tolerances you adhere to.. That's why when you buy quality fitments and make sure they are installed properly, you can leave your workshop for the weekend, come back and still have full compressor tanks.. ☺ Buy cheap tat of fleabay however, and you'll come back to zip 😔

It's not really "that" remarkable. o-rings and when needed seals operate in very many media when a separation of two spaces is required. I would guess similar seals/o-rings exist on submarine/boat propeller/rudder shafts, these seals exist in many shafts in internal combustion engines, gearboxes, reduction gears, differentials etc. to prevent oil leakage, so they are not really that... worth jumping up about. you would be surprised though there are only two of them, and not like... 5 or 7 of them, and no outer "seal", to prevent dust or debri damaging the o-rings, also - as the large pressure difference from the side the pressure is applied (obviously from internal side in the ISS, or from the oil side in engine, or water side in a submarine), sometimes circular rubber seals are being deployed, sometimes with a metal reinforcement inside, and have a special rubber "lip" or "rim" on the seal that presses against the sealing surface in order to prevent pressure - and media - leakage. This is actually even more impressive if you think of valve guide seals in an ICE - and think that valves move through those seals several thousands of times every minute for a lifespan of tens of years, and yes they're still rubber (although with a small metal reinforcement ring), and yes they're subject to high temperatures of 100-300 degrees C, and yes they're in chemically aggressive environment - think of oil/gas/diesel and micture of these... so these ISS seals although still doing their job, are not that jaw dropping. yeah astronauts' lives depend on them, but there are 3-6 astronauts on the ISS, and 7 seals in the cuppola, but there are millions of ICEs running around the globe with at least 2, in most cases 16 or even 24 seals in every one, and although let's say stuff like valve guide seals may leak sometimes, leading to valve stem being oily and what eventually causes the car to lose some milliliters of oil and causing some blue smoke, not necessarily an astronaut dying, but i'd say stuff like that - if you think of it, is much more impressive. you're kind of used to the fact and regard it "normal" that ISS is overengineered and all "amazing and stuff". however, I would probably not trust italians to put together my cuppola, but hey - still works, right? anyway - congrats on getting footage from the ISS and from a beautiful italian.

This might come off as a little dismissive, but O-ring interfaces for such a manipulator is not so surprising. people think of the vacuum of space as some super-vacuum that applies tons of pressure to a tiny interface, but that is simply not the case.

Sea level atmospheric pressure is somewhere around 14 PSI.

get rid of that atmosphere, and your pressure differential is just that - 14 PSI.

humans don't really need 14 PSI, we can stand a bit lower, so if you want to be safe, you can lower it to 11 PSI or so, maybe lower.

11- 14 PSI is literally nothing to a decent O-ring.

For perspective, many hydraulic systems use O-Ring seals that can handle upwards of 2000 PSI. those have to be tightly controlled and the O-ring material is different, but it's the same principle.

in the same vein, I really think people would be surprised at how thin and lightweight space capsules and space stations actually are. when you consider that launching something to orbit requires you to literally pay it's weight in gold, mass is at a premium, and when you have highly trained astronauts on a mission that is 100% up-front about the extreme risks involved, then you engineer to a lower safety factor than you would on most "consumer-grade" projects. same is true of fighter aircraft vs. Commercial airliners, etc.

To be sure, the engineers and scientists in these videos are amazing, and their work is well appreciated, but I think dealing with some of the realities and misconceptions of space would be a bit more educational.

Hey Destin, it may be scary to think that only two O-rings stand between the air you breath and the vacuum of space BUT it is hardly amazing. The ISS has one atmosphere of pressure, or about 14.7 psi. That's nothing. A normal SCUBA tank is filled to 200 atmospheres, or about 3,000 psi and only one O-ring is holding all that pressure when connected to the regulator. A regulator has an internal O-ring as well and it is dynamic, always moving with every breath you take. Now THAT'S impressive engineering. 3,000 psi is a lot of potential energy, basically a bomb waiting to explode. 14.7 psi is nothing, if you put 14.7 psi of pressure in your bicycle tire, you would simply have a flat tire. There, I just gave you an idea for your next video... How a SCUBA regulator works. It's very simple yet surprisingly effective and not a lot of people actually know how it works. This makes a lot of sense, especially if you use dry lubricants. Although you can also use metals as seals. It would be harder for the outer seal, easier for the inner. Because the inner seal would be closer to human tolerances and wouldn't shrink as much. There are actually many ways you could do this, but rubber seals were a lot easier to create when the space station had originally launched. Polymers might make a better choice now, due to the ability to make better artificial seals than rubber.

And honestly, today, it would be entirely cheaper to create an electric motor. There would be a lot less gap, and easier to fix/replace. A simple electric motor can be re-wrapped and re-fitted with wiring that's easily replaceable.

Apollo, and more space hoaxes • Re: Does Rocketry Work in the Vacuum?
by Boethius on Jan 28, 2015 6:58 AM
The reason space travel is not possible is because the systems we claim to use to propel a rocket through space operate on gas pressure and there is no gas pressure in space.

Gas pressure requires molecules to be in contact with each other, bouncing off each other, causing millions of collisions per second, etc… If you release gas into the vacuum of space, the first molecule that pops out will shoot off into the distance at a constant speed, so will the one behind that, never catching up with the first one. The third, fourth, etc… all fly off into the distance trying to fill the vacuum by finding their empty corner. So no matter how much gas you produce none of it will ever change the pressure under a space ship. None it if will ever push a spaceship. To push a spaceship there must be some locally high pressure under it, which is impossible since the pressure in space is 0 everywhere.

Back the the Nozzle and the Massflow equation F=MA on earth
Think about a fire hose shooting water. A force comes directly back against the column of water shooting out. Why? Because the first drop of water has to pas through air, which is dense, causing many collisions, slowing down the drop of water. The second drop, directly behind the first, will not be slowed down by the air so it will collide with the first drop, the third drop hits the second drop and so on, the fast water coming through the hose pushing through the slower water outside causes Newton’s 3rd Law to push back on the column of water. This is why you need people holding the hose to add an unbalanced force otherwise the hose would not be able to push water through that column anymore, the water column would be diverted and the hose would flop around. It is obvious that one drop of water does not push back on the hose, you need a fast moving column.

The nozzle and the Massflow equation in space
Since the molecules leaving the combustion chamber and entering the vacuum never slow down, never collide with any outside objects, nor with each other, their force is always moving forward, away from the ship. There is no way for that force to be returned to the ship. There is no way for the force of the moving molecules to be extracted and used for propulsion. Their force is carried off into the far corners of space. This is also known as Joule Expansion. Remember that as soon as the nozzle is opened, the combustion chamber becomes part of the vacuum of space as is subject to its laws. A closed chamber is under pressure but not an open one.

O-rings that move about are really not a big deal.

For example, any SCUBA regulator will have at least one O-ring that has 200 bars (3000 psi) on one side and 10 bars (150 psi) on the other, with a movable tube in the middle that, when in use, will move hundreds of times per minute. That thing will last for years without having to be replaced.

Compare this to the space station, which has 1 bar (15 psi) on one side and 0 bar on the other, and whose shaft moves what? 4-5 times per day? Sounds like a vacation compared to a SCUBA regulator...

As safety critical as those O-ring seals are, they only need to hold back (at most) ~15 PSI of pressure over a relatively small area.

That's not much at all. The seals around the prop-shaft that hold the water out of a boat are under more stress, because there is both more differential pressure and the shaft is turning faster.
It's amazing because it has to work in space, not because it's a particularly physically demanding sealing application. They probably need to use some special material for the o-rings so they don't degrade from constant exposure to vacuum, wide temperature fluctuations, the abrasion from the shaft turning, and probably a few other constraints. Probably a type of silicone rubber if I had to guess.

when done correctly, o-rings and their groves will hold pressure extremely well. In 9th grade, back when schools had top notch metal-shops, & with the help of an engineer/teacher, I made a plexiglass case for a camera so I could take pictures underwater when diving off California.
I had 2 shafts, 1- to forward the film and 1- to snap the picture. On a trip to San Nicholas island, I went down to 65 feet for 30 minutes with zero leakage. I still have that case & the original baggie of the o-rings. I have no idea where the photos might be... in a box somewhere? LOL

Vacuum of space is not a big pressure difference. Not even a single bar pressure difference between the interior of the ISS and the outside.
O rings are capable of much more! On some applications, the exact same design can withstand pressures in the hundreds of bars (hydraulics for example), and in both static and dynamic situations.
Still, great video showing the inside of the ISS, but not so thrilled by the engineering behind this as you were :)

If holding back a paltry 5 PSI of air pressure seems amazing, check out the seals used in high pressure (as much as 50,000 PSI) hydraulic systems.  A leak there isn't just a leak; it's a liquid laser that can decapitate and dismember in the blink of an eye.  Offshore cementing systems operate at 10,000 to 20,000 psi and are hastily piped with articulating pipe sections via sledge-hammer actuated collars, like the old "knock-off" style wheels on sports cars.

The engineering required to fulfill the requirements of the Cupola module are exacting for sure, but if you think about it it's not that amazing. You are retaining the inner atmosphere against the (not quite hard) vacuum of space - a pressure differential of 1 atmosphere. To put that into perspective, roughly 10 meters of water also create a pressure of 1 atmosphere. Modern submarines have rated depths of up to nearly 500 meters - so a differential of roughly 50 atmospheres. Obviously the design requirements are vastly different between a submarine and a space craft/station, but many of the principles will be the same or broadly similar.

It's certainly a cool application, but it's hardly an example of extreme engineering.  The ISS is pressurized to sea level atmosphere, or about 15 PSI above vacuum.  Your average home water faucet handle holds back 3 to 5 times that amount of pressure without you ever thinking about it. ;)

Granted, it's a water seal, not a gas seal, and it's a lot less failure-critical, but still, 15 PSI is well within the realm of everyday experience and engineering.

What's Interesting about this device that is even though it is mechanical, it takes relatively less force on the operator's part to shut/open the windows and from the video of the astronaut we could see that it doesn't take a lot of wrestling around to get the outer shutter moving, why this is interesting to me is because the axis of pivot of the outer window(which looks heavy) is 90 degrees to the axis of the shaft used by the astronaut for controlling the movement of the shutter, to do this it would require a gear train mechanism for changing the axis of the applied torque from the operator's perspective to the shutter's perspective, and if we want a relatively fast rotation of the end effector as compared to that of the manually operated shaft on the inside of the cupola(the end effector being the shaft which directly controls the movement of the shutter)  then it would require more torque on the operator's part which would be converted to velocity of the shutter by the gear mechanism....so I feel that the window looks heavy but in fact may be relatively light which is why even after the reduction of torque and increase of speed because of the gear mechanism the movement of the shutter is so fast and responsive.... but as stated by astronaut Don Pettit if these shutters are used for protecting against micro-meteorites then they have to thick and dense enough to stop these tiny hyper-sonic pieces of dust....so the material is dense, thick and light weight such that it can stop micro-meteorites and at the same time can be manipulated manually without noticeable effort ....I guess that is why they are called NASA !!   :)

I love this video and I love your work! I do have a little problem with you fascination with the "O" rings. In a simple shaft seal for those shutter mechanisms, It's an elegant yet common  solution. If you want a marvel of engineering, look into the "hard" joints and seals at the elbow of the EVA suit! They are an amazing bit of articulation sensation: 8" dia. low-friction seal. There are seals in common diesel engines that are working against 30k psi pressure! The rubber "O" ring seal is an amazing and underrated piece of engineering.

The handle on your kitchen sink uses a similar O-ring design. When the rings go bad, the handle sprays.

When you rotate the arm on the sink spigot, the same thing works to keep water from spraying out of the gap between the spigot and the valve.

Grease... grease keeps them from wearing out.

When I replaced my sink valve I dutifully gooped on a goodly amount of the supplied grease. Now that the weather is warmer, the water slowly turns itself off as the handle gradually lowers itself.

You wash faster when you start to see the handle stealthily stealing your water!

The thing that is most difficult for me to understand however is how difficult it is. I have made high pressure seals, with dynamic o rings for certain applications that require movement in a pressurized chamber. The thing that is interesting is that the life span is the primary difference. My seals were made with a .0005" precision, but they only last about 6 months under a 120PSI differential. On the other end of the spectrum both in altitude and pressure, there are hundreds of holes in the pressure hull or "people tank" on our submarines floating about in the oceans.  These holes are where hull penetrators are installed to allow electrical or fiber optic connections to pass from inside the pressure hull to outside in the ballast tanks, sail, or other external locations on the boats.  The body of the penetrator and two rubber o-rings are what keeps many, many hundreds of PSI of water from entering into the pressure hull.

SmarterEveryDay, The O-rings DO leak.  They just don't leak a lot.  There is a large quantity of air inside the space station.  If each O-ring leaked one cc/day of air it would take years to reduce the inside pressure of the space station significantly. 

The question is not how to reduce the leak rate to zero because that is impossible and not necessary.  The engineer has to reduce the leak rate to an acceptable level at an acceptable cost.  Additionally, the engineer has to reduce shaft drag so the mechanism can be operated easily.

There are probably over a hundred leak sites on the ISS.  Each site has a leak budget for the engineer to design to.

Huh. The whole time i thought the shutters were electronically operated with motors. I thought it would be more structurally sound and simpler to feed a wire to power motors compared to a direct mechanical assembly. More sound and more simple in the sense that the wires would only require a small hole thus easier to seal and less likely to fail or get damaged. Now I guess they were aiming for reliability.

Note: Im not saying the current design is unsafe and not simple. The people who approved this design clearly saw something I did not. Unreliability is its own danger (by forcing astronauts to take space-walks).

I have been chasing a leak in a High Vac test chamber for the last few weeks. It is easy to think that there is enormous vacuum pressure in space. Atmospheric air pressure at sea level is about 15 psi. So if the space station was pressurized to sea level pressure (which I am sure it is not) the differential would only be 15psi. Nearly every pressure vessel you come in contact with on a daily basis tolerates a higher differential. It would certainly be concerning to have your air supply weeping out into space though.

To me, this isn't really that amazing. Using o-rings for seals between areas that have a difference in pressure is extremely common. In fact, the o-rings used in an air compressor are actually more impressive, in my opinion, because they have a much higher pressure difference between them. I mean, with the space station, we're talking a measly 14.7 psi of pressure and that's assuming they always keep it at 1 atm in there. I don't know for sure, but I would suspect they keep it at an even lower pressure than that considering humans can live comfortably at much lower pressures (down to 0.5 atm or so before it becomes noticeably uncomfortable--not taking into account the O2 concentration). So, yeah, those o-rings have to withstand less pressure than the o-rings in your bike tire pump and they work on a very similar design/principal.

Still, a GREAT video!!
